The post Pulse wins two awards for GP recruitment coverage appeared first on Pulse Today.

A cyber attack impacting NHS pathology labs in London hospitals has left GPs ‘flying blind’ with delays to test results and cancelled hospital appointments.  Synnovis, a provider of lab services for a group of London hospitals, was the ‘victim of a ransomware cyberattack’ which caused ‘interruptions’ to its pathology services, HSJ revealed yesterday.  The company
The post GPs fear delayed test results amid major cyber attack on NHS pathology appeared first on Pulse Today.

The next Government should take urgent action to address GP unemployment, the BMA has demanded in its general election manifesto. It confirmed to Pulse that it was referring
The post BMA election manifesto demands action on GP unemployment appeared first on Pulse Today.

A group representing anaesthetists of all grades has raised over £25,000 to fund a legal challenge against the GMC over its handling of the regulation of physician associates (PAs) and anaesthetist associates (AAs). Anaesthetists United said it is commencing a legal case against the regulator as it believes the regulation process is ‘blurring the distinction’

The post GP workload concern as private hospital admissions reach ‘record level’ appeared first on Pulse Today.

The post Pharmacy First would be expanded to acne and chest infections under Tories appeared first on Pulse Today.

The Government has brought in an emergency ban on private prescribing of puberty blockers to children and young people. Earlier this year, NHS England banned routine prescription of puberty blockers on the NHS for children with gender dysphoria, after a working group found there is not sufficient evidence to support their ‘safety or clinical effectiveness’.

The post Ambulance crews ‘bullying’ practices to access GP, warn LMCs appeared first on Pulse Today.

The post Antibiotic prescribing concerns ‘so far unfounded’, say Pharmacy First leaders appeared first on Pulse Today.

The post GP practices face closure due to eight-year long rent dispute appeared first on Pulse Today.

The post Private provider to make remote GPs redundant at five practices appeared first on Pulse Today.

The latest figures show rates of whooping cough are continuing to rise after a post-pandemic

The removal of varenicline from the UK market in 2021 after impurities were found in supplies may have led to thousands fewer people attempting to stop smoking, researchers have estimated. The post Withdrawal of varenicline in UK led to thousands fewer quit attempts appeared first on Pulse Today.

The post GPs will use AI to reduce antibiotic prescribing under Government five-year plan appeared first on Pulse Today.

Women who consume eight or more alcoholic drinks a week are significantly more likely to develop heart disease than those who drink less, researchers have found. Claire Dellar talks about her experience of using assistive technology and explains how other people’s choices not to prioritise accessibility affect her.


I spend a lot of time in conversations that start something like this:


“I’m really sorry I can’t fill in that report, it’s not accessible to me. Can you send it in another format?”
articles.title: Accessibility is a choice

articles.description:
Liz Gaffney, Head of NHS England's Secure Data Environment, reflects on the developments of the service one year on.


In January, Michael Chapman blogged about our ambitious plans for the NHS England Secure Data Environment (SDE), starting with migrating customers to the service, testing its capabilities and processes, and then scaling up the service to handle wider use.
articles.title: One year on: The latest on our Secure Data Environment

articles.author: enquiries@nhsdigital.nhs.uk (NHS Digital)
articles.description:
For International Clinical Trials Day, James Gray, NHS DigiTrials Service Delivery Manager, talks about the new Feasibility Self-Service tool that drastically cuts the time it takes researchers to find out if there are enough potential participants for their clinical trial.


“In the time it takes to make a coffee.”


That was the challenge we set ourselves early in the creation of the NHS DigiTrials Feasibility Self-Service tool. And it was a big one: it meant giving users the ability to securely interrogate national datasets containing millions and millions of records in less than 5 minutes.
articles.title: Clinical trials get faster

Landmark resolution passed on health and climate change
In a resounding call to action, the Seventy-seventh World Health Assembly has recognized climate change as an imminent threat to global health, passing a resolution which underscores the urgent need for decisive measures to confront the profound health risks posed by climate change.
The resolution, supported overwhelmingly by Member States, presents an overview of the existential threat that climate change poses to human health. The Health Assembly asserts that radical action is imperative to safeguard the health of the planet, underscoring the interdependence of environmental sustainability and public health.
Urging the global health community to mobilize on an unprecedented scale, the Health Assembly calls for the amplification and …

However, there is still an apparent insufficient growth in and asymmetrical development of transplantation worldwide with many countries not having established the appropriate systems, including legislation, governance, specialized workforce, …

First-ever resolution on social participation for primary health care approved

Member States have agreed on a resolution on social participation in national health planning and implementation, which paves the way for people, communities, and civil society to have a stronger voice in influencing the decisions that affect their health and well-being. 

The resolution aims to tackle health inequities and the erosion of trust in health systems, which is crucial in the face of the unprecedented challenges the world is facing such as climate change, conflicts, and pandemic threats. 

Growing evidence shows the transformative potential of social participation to foster trust in health systems, advance equity and align healthcare with people’s lived experiences. Two-way dialogues between governme…

articles.description:
The World Health Assembly (WHA) today recognized the progress made over the past two years by Member States to develop a pandemic agreement and strengthen the International Health Regulations (IHR, 2005). Governments meeting in Geneva for the Seventy-seventh World Health Assembly are in talks to advance these two efforts, which aim to boost the world’s ability to better able to prevent and respond to the threat of future pandemics.
 
WHO Member States agreed to continue to work during the World Health Assembly, which ends on 1 June, with the aim to:

finalize the package of amendments to the IHR (2005)
agree the timing, format and process to conclude the pandemic agreement.

 During today’s session, the WHA first considered agenda item 13.4 on the draft pandemic agreement. Delegates acknowledged the extensive work undertaken by the Member State-led Intergovernmental Negotiating Body (INB), and the Bureau steering the work, since governments launched the process in December 2021 to develop the world’s first pandemic accord to prevent a repeat of the global health, economic and social impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic.
 
Member States reiterated that the world needs a pandemic agreement built on the principles of equity, sovereignty, and prevention, preparedness and response, and to ensure future generations are safeguarded from the threat of inevitable future pandemics.
 
WHA delegates also considered agenda item 13.3, which laid out the work undertaken to negotiate the amendments to the International Health Regulations(2005) to build on lessons learned from the global response to the COVID-19 pandemic.  
 
Member States stressed that agreement on updated and stronger International Health Regulations were essential for ensuring global health security.
articles.title: WHO Member States agree way forward to conclude Pandemic Agreement

articles.description:
World Health Assembly approves a global health strategy fit for a challenging future 

Delegates at the Seventy-seventh World Health Assembly (WHA 77) approved a four-year, US$ 11.1 billion strategy for global health to promote, provide, and protect health and well-being for all people, with an emphasis on climate change, aging, migration, pandemic threats, and equity, and adapted for a time of fast-moving geopolitics, science and technology. 

The strategy, the Fourteenth General Programme of Work   (GPW 14), treats 2025–2028 as an exceptional window of opportunity to build resilient, fit-for-future health systems and, in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic, to get back on track to reach the health-related Sustainable Development Goals.

GPW 14 has six strategic objectives which reflect maj…

articles.description:
UNICEF delivered over 43 000 doses of the R21/Matrix-M malaria vaccine by air to Bangui, Central African Republic, today, with more than 120 000 doses to follow in the next days. It is the first country to receive the R21 malaria vaccine for use in routine childhood immunization, marking another step forward in preventing the disease and saving children’s lives.   

R21 is the second malaria vaccine to be recommended by WHO for children living in endemic areas. Along with the earlier WHO recommendation of the RTS,S vaccine, there is now sufficient vaccine supply to scale up malaria vaccination in Africa. The rollout of both vaccines is funded by Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance. 

“With two products now available to countries, expanded supply of malaria vaccines is a game changer for child survi…
articles.title: Shipment of newest malaria vaccine, R21, to Central African Republic marks latest milestone for child survival

articles.description:
Mpox continues to affect people around the world. A new  framework released today by WHO will guide health authorities, communities and other stakeholders in preventing and controlling mpox outbreaks, eliminating human-to-human transmission of the disease, and reducing spillover of the virus from animals to humans.
Mpox is a viral illness caused by the monkeypox virus (MPXV). It can cause a painful rash, enlarged lymph nodes and fever. Most people fully recover, but some get very sick. The virus transmits from person to person through close, including sexual, contact. It also has animal reservoirs in east, central and west Africa, where spillovers from animals to humans can occasionally occur, sparking further outbreaks. 
There are two different clades of the virus: clade I and clade II. Clade I outbreaks are deadlier than clade II outbreaks. 
A major emergence of mpox linked to clade II began in 2017, and since 2022, has spread to all regions of the world. Between July 2022 and May 2023, the outbreak was declared a Public Health Emergency of International Concern. While that outbreak has largely subsided, cases and deaths continue to be reported today, illustrating that low-level transmission continues around the world. 
Currently, there is also a  major outbreak of clade I virus in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), where cases have been on the rise for decades. Since the beginning of the year, over 6500 cases and 345 deaths have been reported in the DRC. Almost half of these are among children under the age of 15 years.
The Strategic framework for enhancing prevention and control of mpox (2024–2027) provides a roadmap for health authorities, communities, and stakeholders worldwide to control mpox outbreaks in every context, advance mpox research and access to countermeasures, and to minimize zoonotic transmission.
articles.title: WHO releases a strategic framework for enhancing prevention and control of mpox

articles.description:
The latest edition of the  World Health Statistics released today by the World Health Organization (WHO) reveals that the COVID-19 pandemic reversed the trend of steady gain in life expectancy at birth and healthy life expectancy at birth (HALE). 
The pandemic wiped out nearly a decade of progress in improving life expectancy within just two years. Between 2019 and 2021, global life expectancy dropped by 1.8 years to 71.4 years (back to the level of 2012). Similarly, global healthy life expectancy dropped by 1.5 years to 61.9 years in 2021 (back to the level of 2012).
The 2024 report also highlights how the effects have been felt unequally across the world. The WHO regions for the Americas and South-East Asia were hit hardest, with life expectancy dropping by approximately 3 years and heal…
articles.title: COVID-19 eliminated a decade of progress in global level of life expectancy

articles.description:
Ahead of the World Health Assembly 77, Qatar Fund for Development (QFFD) and the World Health Organization (WHO) have signed Core Contribution Agreement to support the implementation of the extended 13th WHO Programme of Work.
The agreement entails a contribution of $4 million from the State of Qatar to WHO, through QFFD, aimed at enhancing the Organization's efforts in addressing global health challenges. This partnership underscores the State of Qatar and QFFD's unwavering commitment to improving health outcomes and promoting sustainable development goals worldwide.
"Our partnership with WHO is a testament to our dedication to leaving no one behind in the pursuit of health equity worldwide. By supporting WHO, we aim to empower communities, enhance healthcare access, and contribute to a healthier future for all." Said Mr Sultan Ahmed Al-Aseeri, Acting Director-General of QFFD.
“Flexible funds are critical for WHO’s life-saving work. With thanks to long-standing partners like the Qatar Fund for Development, WHO can use these funds to swiftly respond to global health needs as they arise. I am grateful to the State of Qatar for their support and for allowing us the flexibility we need to carry out our mission and mandate,‘’ said WHO Director-General Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus.
The extended 13th WHO Programme of Work (GWP13) focuses on a comprehensive approach to health, addressing communicable and non-communicable diseases, strengthening health systems, and promoting health through the life course. This collaboration will particularly emphasize supporting countries in crisis and post-crisis contexts, aligning with the State of Qatar and QFFD's mission to provide crucial aid where it is needed most.
As the world continues to navigate complex health challenges, the partnership between QFFD and WHO represents a beacon of hope and a model for international cooperation in the realm of global health. This agreement is a significant step towards achieving the shared goal of a healthier, more resilient world.
articles.title: Qatar Fund for Development (QFFD) supports the implementation of WHO's extended 13th General Programme of Work with flexible funding

The report shows that globally an estimated 37 million children aged 13–15 years use tobacco, and in many countries, the rate of e-cigarette use among adolescents exceeds that of adults. In the WHO European Region, 20% of 15-year-olds surveyed reported using e…
articles.title: Tobacco and nicotine industry tactics addict youth for life

articles.description:
In an historic milestone for global public health, State Parties today agreed in principle on a large, ground-breaking package of amendments to the International Health Regulations (2005). These amendments build on over 300 proposals made by countries in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic. They set out to improve the ability of countries to prepare for, detect and respond to Public Health Emergencies of International Concern (PHEICs), and will be part of a package to be put forward to the World Health Assembly (WHA). The WHA takes place from 27 May–1 June 2024. Negotiators will meet again next week to wrap up their work on the few remaining issues that need to be finalised. 
The IHR, which were first adopted by the World Health Assembly in 1969 and last revised in 2005, were conceived to ma…
articles.title: Ground-breaking progress made in Member State negotiations on amendments to the International Health Regulations (IHR)

articles.description:
The World Health Organization (WHO) publishes the first global guidelines to prevent the occurrence of bloodstream and other infections caused by use of catheters placed in minor blood vessels during medical procedures.
Poor practices in the insertion, maintenance, and removal of these catheters carry a high risk of introducing germs directly to the bloodstream, which can lead to serious conditions such as sepsis, and difficult-to-treat complications in major organs like the brain and kidneys. Soft tissue infections at the insertion site of the catheter can also occur.

Up to 70% of all inpatients require the use of a catheter inserted into a peripheral vein or artery, also known as peripherally inserted catheters (PIVCs), at some point during their hospital stay.  People who receive treat…
articles.title: New guidance aims to reduce bloodstream infections from catheter use

articles.description: Following the government announcement of a general election, we asked health tech leaders and think tanks what the priorities should be for digital health.
articles.title: General election 2024: Health leaders share their views on digital priorities

articles.author: Jordan Sollof
articles.description: Today's briefing includes Bruntwood SciTech launching its new Life Science Accelerator programme and a new 24/7 mobile service in Neath Port Talbot.
articles.title: Digital Health Coffee Time Briefing ☕

articles.author: DHI News Team
articles.description: Around 300 children and young people in Leicester will be given smart inhalers that monitor use via a smartphone app, as part of an NHS-funded study.
articles.title: Leicester launches NHS trial of smart inhalers for children

articles.author: Jordan Sollof
articles.description: Entries for Digital Health Rewired Pitchfest 2025 are now open to start-ups, providing the opportunity to pitch to an audience of NHS leaders and investors.
articles.title: Digital Health Rewired Pitchfest 2025 entries now open to start-ups

articles.author: Jordan Sollof
articles.description: The Department of Health and Social Care has published a tender to secure an organisation to develop the digital skills of the adult social care workforce.
articles.title: DHSC publishes social care digital skills support tender worth £475k

articles.author: Jordan Sollof
articles.description: Surrey and Borders Partnership NHS FT has selected Better to provide a new digital health platform and Avenue3 to implement a mental health patient portal.
articles.title: Surrey and Borders select Better and Avenue3 for new integrated platform

articles.author: Jordan Sollof
articles.description: The Guernsey Government has announced that the first phase of the island's EPR implementation has been delayed to 2025 due to patient safety.
articles.title: First implementation phase of Guernsey’s new EPR delayed to 2025

articles.author: Jordan Sollof
articles.description: The Government of Jersey is awarding up to £2 million to technology solutions that improve the lives and wellbeing of Jersey’s rapidly ageing population.
articles.title: Jersey Gov to award £2m to tech that can support ageing population

articles.author: Tammy Lovell
articles.description: This briefing features Aliter acquiring healthcare ICT provider Bates IT and Apple Watch’s AFib feature being approved as a medical device by the FDA.
articles.title: Digital Health Coffee Time Briefing ☕

articles.author: Tammy Lovell
articles.description: Rotherham NHS Foundation Trust has announced the launch of a diagnostic booking solution, developed in partnership with Netcall.
articles.title: Rotherham NHS FT rolls out diagnostic booking solution

articles.author: Jordan Sollof
articles.description: NHS England and NICE have outlined a joint proposal to help fast-track clinically and cost-effective products for use by the healthcare system.
articles.title: NHS England and NICE announce plan to speed up innovative tech adoption

articles.author: Cora Lydon
articles.description: WhatsApp and an AI receptionist are being piloted at North Central London ICB, in a pilot to see if the tools can boost uptake of cervical cancer screening.
articles.title: North Central London ICB pilots WhatsApp and AI appointment scheduling

articles.author: Cora Lydon
articles.description: East and North Hertfordshire plans to phase out its bleeps system and introduce the Alertive app to improve communication between clinical teams.
articles.title: East and North Hertfordshire to replace bleeps with messaging app

articles.author: Cora Lydon
articles.description: Historic data collected from Bedfordshire Hospitals NHS FT is being used in a simulation project to help enhance patient journeys in clinics.
articles.title: Bedfordshire Hospitals’ data supports simulation project

articles.author: Jordan Sollof
articles.description: The three trusts that form the Acute Hospital Alliance are to implement a new shared electronic patient record (EPR), which will go live in 2026.
articles.title: Three Acute Hospital Alliance trusts to implement shared EPR

articles.author: Tammy Lovell
articles.description: This briefing features Holly Health partnering with Loughborough University to deliver multimorbidity app Prevent and Pharmacy2u acquiring the PharmPet Co.
articles.title: Digital Health Coffee Time Briefing ☕

articles.author: Jordan Sollof
articles.description: Digital Health is delighted to announce that NHS England’s CIO John Quinn will return as keynote at Summer Schools 2024 in July.
articles.title: National CIO John Quinn returns as Summer Schools keynote in 2024

articles.author: Tammy Lovell
articles.description: NHS England has announced proposals to increase access to virtual wards in a bid to reduce emergency department (ED) waiting times.
articles.title: NHS England sets ambition to improve access to virtual wards

articles.author: Jordan Sollof
articles.description: The Irish Health Service Executive has launched a digital framework, including plans to roll out a patient app and national shared care record.
articles.title: Ireland announces plans to roll out patient app and shared care record

articles.author: Jordan Sollof
articles.description: The Scottish Government has confirmed that its ‘Cloud First’ digital health strategy has been delayed following a recent budget review and settlement.
articles.title: Scottish Government ‘Cloud First’ strategy delayed following budget review

articles.author: Cora Lydon
articles.description: Liverpool Women's NHS Foundation Trust is set to deploy Netcall's Patient Hub in autumn 2024 to streamline communications and empower patients.
articles.title: Liverpool Women’s NHS FT to roll out Netcall patient hub

articles.author: Jordan Sollof
articles.description: Kettering and Northampton General Hospitals have become the first pilot sites to transition to a local instance of the NHS Federated Data Platform (FDP).
articles.title: Northamptonshire hospitals are first to transition to local instance of FDP

articles.author: Tammy Lovell
articles.description: Digital Health Coffee Time Briefing today includes UK healthcare operations software provider Agilio acquiring PraQties, and a digital tool to determine eligibility for NHS-funded IVF and IUI.
articles.title: Digital Health Coffee Time Briefing ☕

articles.author: Tammy Lovell
articles.description: The leader of one of Europe’s most successful regional health information digitisation programmes, will be a keynote at Digital Health Summer Schools 2024.
articles.title: Dr Jordi Piera Jiménez confirmed as keynote at Summer Schools 2024

articles.author: Cora Lydon
articles.description: A smartphone app which aims to deliver more personalised care to Parkinson's disease patients is being trialled at Leeds Teaching Hospitals NHS Trust.
articles.title: Leeds Teaching Hospitals pilots app for Parkinson’s disease

articles.author: Jordan Sollof
articles.description: West Hertfordshire has invested in two more robotic surgery machines with the aim of enabling cancer patients to go home within 24 hours of an operation.
articles.title: West Hertfordshire invests more than £2.5m in surgical robots in 2024

articles.author: Cora Lydon
articles.description: NHS Lanarkshire has tested a digital system that determines how ill emergency department patients are and prioritises their treatment accordingly.
articles.title: NHS Lanarkshire trials Patientrack digital patient observation system in ED

articles.author: Cora Lydon
articles.description: A full blood count analyser from Entia has received the UKCA mark and is set to be deployed at two NHS trusts this September, with more to follow.
articles.title: Entia at-home full blood count analyser to be deployed at NHS trusts

articles.author: Cora Lydon
articles.description: Research commissioned by MHRA and NICE found that patients believe digital mental health technologies should be used alongside other treatments.
articles.title: Patients prefer DMHT to be ‘part of wider treatment package’, says report

articles.author: Jordan Sollof
articles.description: A project using interactive light technology from Social-Ability to provide activities and games for care home residents living with dementia is underway.
articles.title: Light tech project launched across 10 care homes for dementia patients

articles.author: Jordan Sollof
articles.description: This roundup includes six trusts rolling out a digital tool for mental health care, and UHDB and CRH signing a joint contract for a new Nervecentre EPR.
articles.title: Digital Health’s monthly roundup of contracts and go lives

articles.author: Jordan Sollof
articles.description: Dr Hatim Abdulhussein and Jules Gudgeon have been confirmed as speakers at AI and Data 2024, which will take place at London Olympia, 22-23 October.
articles.title: Abdulhussein and Gudgeon confirmed as AI and Data 2024 speakers

articles.author: Cora Lydon
articles.description: Digital Health Coffee Time Briefing today includes the good news that surfing the web can improve your wellbeing and NHSE research into cyberattacks.
articles.title: Digital Health Coffee Time Briefing ☕

articles.author: Cora Lydon
articles.description: The MHRA has now launched AI Airlock - a regulatory sandbox that will explore the challenges that comes with regulating AI as a medical device.
articles.title: MHRA launches regulatory sandbox for AI medical devices

articles.author: Cora Lydon
articles.description: UK digital health company Careology has teamed up with the US's Evolent to support more connected care pathways for cancer patients in the US.
articles.title: UK digital cancer care platform Careology teams with Evolent Health

articles.author: Tammy Lovell
articles.description: US non-profit health system, Ascension has confirmed that its electronic health records (EHR) system is down following a ransomware incident on 8 May 2024.
articles.title: US firm Ascension says EHR is down following ransomware attack

articles.author: Tammy Lovell
articles.description: Gloucestershire Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust has partnered with DrDoctor to provide an online portal for outpatients, reducing the need for paper letters.
articles.title: Gloucestershire Hospitals NHS FT launches DrDoctor patient portal

articles.author: Cora Lydon
articles.description: The Lenus Diagnose pathway product is set to support earlier diagnoses on the breathlessness diagnostic pathway at Leicester and Hinkley CDCs.
articles.title: Leicester and Hinckley CDCs to roll out digital tool for breathlessness

articles.author: Jordan Sollof
articles.description: NHS England have confirmed that the 2024 Digital Maturity Assessment is an evolution of last year’s survey and includes an expansion into primary care.
articles.title: Digital Maturity Assessment expands into primary care for 2024

articles.author: Tammy Lovell
articles.description: Today's briefing includes NICE recommending breast cancer tools be more available and SleepCogni and Sheffield Children’s tackling insomnia in children.
articles.title: Digital Health Coffee Time Briefing ☕

articles.author: Jordan Sollof
articles.description: Nationally recognised NHS leader and Newcastle Hospitals CEO, Sir Jim Mackey, has been confirmed as an opening keynote at Summer Schools 2024.
articles.title: Sir Jim Mackey confirmed as opening joint Summer Schools 2024 keynote

articles.author: Jordan Sollof
articles.description: The Government of Jersey’s Health and Community Services (HCS) has implemented a new electronic prescription system at Jersey General Hospital.
articles.title: Jersey General Hospital implements electronic prescribing for outpatients

articles.author: Cora Lydon
articles.description: The research resource knowledge bank at Imperial College Healthcare NHS trust has been expanded to all patients, allowing them to be involved with research.
articles.title: Imperial College Healthcare expands patient research database

articles.author: Jordan Sollof
articles.description: NHS England have announced funding of £48m for integrated care boards to fund capabilities relating to digital pathways and demand and capacity tools.
articles.title: ICBs allocated £48m for digital pathways, demand and capacity tools

articles.author: Jordan Sollof
articles.description: Bishoy Dimitri, CCIO at Oxford University Hospitals, chats to Digital Health about his career to date, digital priorities and ambitions for the next year.
articles.title: Bishoy Dimitri: A CCIO on a mission to empower patients

articles.author: Jordan Sollof
articles.description: NHS Dumfries and Galloway are working with the National Cyber Security Centre following the publication of around three terabytes of stolen patient data.
articles.title: NHS Dumfries and Galloway working with NCSC after 3TB data leak

articles.author: Cora Lydon
articles.description: Researchers from Imperial College London are exploring digital twin heart models to see if they are  feasible, scalable and affordable for NHS care pathways.
articles.title: Imperial College London explores use of digital twin heart models

articles.author: Tammy Lovell
articles.description: Six mental health trusts in London to roll out digital tool to support people detained under the Mental Health Act (MHA), OneLondon has announced.
articles.title: OneLondon announces digital tool for mental health care

articles.author: Jordan Sollof
articles.description: Today's briefing includes North Cumbria building a new Community Diagnostic Centre and Agilio announcing its acquisition in the Netherlands, PraQties.
articles.title: Digital Health Coffee Time Briefing ☕

articles.author: Cora Lydon
articles.description: NHS National Services Scotland has implemented Rhapsody's Enterprise Master Person Index (EMPI) on behalf of NHS Scotland.
articles.title: NHS Scotland enhances data connectivity with Rhapsody EMPI

articles.author: Cora Lydon
articles.description: Esri UK's geospatial mapping tool is being used by Airedale General Hospital in the management of its RAAC monitoring and repairs work.
articles.title: Airedale General Hospital uses indoor mapping to manage RAAC repairs

articles.author: Cora Lydon
articles.description: Consultant Connect technology has been rolled out across NHS Lanarkshire, connecting ambulance clinicians with specialist consultants to improve care.
articles.title: NHS Lanarkshire uses Consultant Connect to avoid unnecessary A&E trips

articles.author: Cora Lydon
articles.description: A new study has determined that the Cera AI-led Digital Care Plan platform could save the NHS as much as £1 billion a year.
articles.title: Cera AI-led social care forecast to save NHS £1bn a year

articles.author: Cora Lydon
articles.description: The BadgerNet app is being used by expectant parents at West Hertfordshire Teaching Hospitals NHS Trust, to replace traditional paper notes.
articles.title: West Hertfordshire Teaching Hospitals launches maternity app

articles.author: Cora Lydon
articles.description: Clanwilliam has adapted its iMedDoc practice management solution to bring it to the UK market, offering a flexible workflow for private practices.
articles.title: Clanwilliam launches iMedDoc practice management system to the UK
